다인은 가로저었다.
"안돼."
"안됩니까?"
"성공하더라도 시민들이 얼마나 호응할지 알 수 없어. 즉각 정보통제가 될 거야."
사르쵸가 고개를 떨구고 있자 다인이 말했다.
"…하지만, 다른 계획이 더해지면 쓸모가 있을 거야."
"다른 계획이요?"
"지금까지 성공한 사례는 대체로 제국의 손길이 닿았어. 제일 유명한 루베일 노역장 반란인데, 이건 제국의 외부 조력자들이 있었다고 하고."
사르쵸가 말했다.
"…가능하면 그들의 손을 빌리고 싶진 않은데요."
"나도 마찬가지야. 그런식으로 외부의 힘을 빌리면 혁명의 순수성이 퇴색되고 마니까. 외부의 힘을 빌릴수록 사람들은 거부감을 느끼기도 하고. 그럼 혁명에 동참하는 사람들 숫자도 줄겠지. …내가 말하고 싶은 건, 외부의 조력과 더불어서 혁명의 당사자들 또한 이런 일에 깊은 관심을 가지고 언제든 뛰어들 준비를 해야 한다는 거야."
"안과 밖, 양면으로 말씀이군요."
다인이 고개를 끄덕였다.
"그래. 그러기위해서는 사람들이 동조할 수 있는 환경이 조성되어야 하고. 단순히 사람들에게 진실을 알린다는 것만으로는 사람들을 움직일 수 없어. 사람들이 진실을 받아들일 준비가 되어 있어야 해."
"아까 말씀하신 관계망 말이군요."
"맞아."
"그런 일은 어떻게… 하죠?"
다인이 말했다.
"…그게 문제야. 한 명 한 명을 설득해나가는 과정이 있어야 하는데, 오랜 시간 그걸 반대하는 사람들에게 들키지 않고 이어져 나가야 해. …우리는 이미 한 번 실패했고, 또 실패할 수도 있어. 두 번째 실패는 그냥 끝일지도 모르지."
"…."
"할 수 있겠어? 지난한 일이 될 거야. 당신은 이미 내 총알을 받아냈어. 그걸로 책임을 졌다고 생각하진 않지만… 억지로 이 일에 뛰어들 필요는 없어. 그건 오히려 방해일테니까."
사르쵸가 고개를 들었다.
"다인 씨. 저는 1년 전만 하더라도 이런 이야기를 하게 될 거라고 생각하지 않았습니다. 하지만 지금은 여기에 있죠. 저는 무엇이 저를 바꾸었는지 생각했죠."
"가릴의 죽음이 당신을 바꾼 거야? 연민인가? 아니면 다른 사람들은 모르고 당신은 아는 진실 때문에?"
"모두 맞는 것 같습니다. 하지만 연민과 진실만으로 설명되지 않는 게 있습니다."
"뭐지?"
사르쵸가 어색하게 웃었다.
"저도 잘 모릅니다. 하지만 그걸 알기 위해서 이 일에 뛰어들고자 합니다. 다인 씨와 혁명파 동지들이 동의해주시기만 한다면."
다인은 고개를 살짝 끄덕였다.
다인은 사르쵸의 말을 이해할 수 있었다.
다인 자신도 왜 이렇게까지 일을 벌이는지는 알 수 없는 노릇이다.
이것은 다인이 당장 먹고 사는 일에 도움을 주지도 않고, 앞으로 다인을 행복하게 해준다는 보장도 없었다. 도박꾼들이 주사위를 내던지는 일과 다름 없다.
다인은 이 모든 일이 그저 일종의 자기 파멸을 향한 몸부림, 자살이라고 생각되기도 했는데, 사르쵸의 말처럼 그것만으로는 설명되지 않는 무언가가 있었다.
"좋아. 따라오라고, 동지."
다인이 노동자들을 규합하는 동안, 사르쵸는 자신이 할 수 있는 일을 했다.
신문기자들과 개인적인 친분을 돈독히 하면서 동시에, 슈바넬 내부에서 벌어지고 있으나 계속해서 묵과되는 범죄들에 대해 이야기를 끌어냈다.
처음에는 다들 그런 이야기를 하는 것을 어색해하거나 난감해했지만, 남들이 쉽게 들을 수 없는 자리에서 맛있는 음식으로 배를 불리고 술에 거나하게 취하면 속내를 여과없이 떠들어대기도 했다.
그 과정에서 사르쵸는 귀족과 공장주들이 어떤 범죄적 행위를 저지르는지도 알게 되었다.
사르쵸는 슈바넬 내부의 부동산 가격과 공장주들, 고리대금업자들이 긴밀한 관계를 가지고 있다는 사실을 알 수 있었다.
코가 벌게지도록 술을 들이킨 기자 하나가 말했다.
"사제님, 그러니까, 잘 보십쇼. 노동자들의 불만을 관리하는 건 쉬운 겁니다. 우선은, 노동자들이 말하는 요구 사항을 조금 들어 준다고 칩시다. 일하는 시간을 한 시간 정도 줄여준다거나 하는 걸 들어줘요. 그런데 비슷한 시기에 부동산을 가진 귀족들이 집세를 올립니다. 생활비가 빠듯해지니 처음엔 고리대금업자들에게 돈을 빌리죠. 빚을 못 갚잖아요? 그럼 노동자 몇 명이 빚에 쪼달리다가 임금을 올려달라고 사정을 하죠. 그럼 공장주들이 우리는 해달라는 거 다해줬는데 하면서 거드름을 피는 겁니다. 그럼 그때가서 노동자들이 일할 시간을 늘려달라고 사정을 합니다. 공장주들은 왜 이제와서 일을 되돌리냐며 화를 내며 전보다 좀더 많이 일하도록 만드는 거죠."
사르쵸가 말했다.
"그걸 아무도… 문제라고 생각하진 않는건가?"
기자가 말했다.
"알 사람은 다 아니까요.. 노예라고 직접적으로 부르진 않지만 노동자라는 건 죄다 노예나 다름없습니다. 어떤 면에선 오히려 노예보다 더 나쁘죠. 노예는 주인과 직접적인 관계에 있으니, 그 주인만 죽이면 끝날 일입니다. 하지만 노동자라는 건 이 모든 사회 시스템에 엮인 상태니까, 누구 하나 죽인다고 끝날 일도 아니죠. 생각해보십쇼, 노동자 하나가 공장주 하나를 죽였다고 칩시다. 그 공장이 팔린다고 공장이 사라진답니까? 다른 공장주가 그 공장을 매입하겠죠. 그게 답니다. 과거에 계급은 흔들리고 불안정했지만, 현대의 계급은 더 탄탄해졌죠. 어지간해선 흔들 수 없습니다."
이런 술자리들이 사르쵸에게만 기여한 것은 아니었다.
기자들은 다음날 아침이면 깨질듯한 머리를 쥐면서, 자신이 어젯밤 무슨 이야기를 하고 들었는지를 어렴풋하게 기억했다.
그런 기자들은 시청을 드나들고 귀족들에게 식사 대접을 받고 공장주들에게 뒷돈을 받으면서도, 순간순간 자신이 했던 말들을 기억했다.
기자 몇몇은 그런 화두에 관심을 가진 사르쵸를 불편해하며 멀리했다.
하지만 어떤 이들은 사르쵸의 술자리를 즐겼다.
그들은 자신들이 술기운을 빌려 했던 말들이, 사실은 자신이 정말로 하고 싶었던 말은 아닌지, 기사로 쓰고 싶었으나 결국 쓰고 싶었던 글은 아닌지를 곱씹었다.
그런 한편, 사르쵸는 개인적인 조사를 통해서 자본가들이 어떻게 노동자들에게 압박을 가하고 불법적이고 비윤리적인 자산을 축적해나갔는가를 알아보았다.
이러한 자료와 정보들은 다인에게 옮겨졌고, 다인은 이러한 내용을 노동자들을 규합하는데 사용했다.
사르쵸의 이야기에는 단순히 뜬소문이 아니라 명백한 증거들에 바탕을 두고 있었고, 이는 다인의 '동지'들을 설득하는 것을 넘어 막연한 미래에 대한 불안과 고통을, 자신의 잘못이 아니라 사회 구조가 내포하고 있던 부조리들을 직시하게 만들었다.
다인의 문제는 그런 내부에서 치솟는 불길을 어떻게든 잠재우고 숨기는 것이었다.
사람들은 이제 부조리에 대해서 알았고, 왜 자신들이 행복하게 살 수 없는지, 무미와 유미들이 어떻게 다르지 않은지, 무미들의 선조들이 겪은 패배 때문에 지금까지 고통받는 것이 얼마나 납득할 수 없는 일인지 이해했다.
인쇄소 노동자들은 공장주 몰래 기계를 돌려 책자를 찍었고, 신문을 돌리는 꼬마들은 신문을 팔면서 노동자들에게 책자를 나누었고, 목공소에서 피켓을 만들고 방직 공장에서 여분의 천을 빼돌렸다. 염료 공장에서 염료를 날랐다.
하지만 다인은 단호했다. 지금 움직일 수는 없다.
동지들은 움직이고 싶어했으나 보다 큰 겁화가 되기 위해서는 때를 기다려야 했다.
사르쵸 또한 동의했다.
다른 문제도 있었다.
다인은 이전의 혁명파가 하나의 집단으로 규합하는 게 위험하다고 판단했고 개인이 하나의 분파를 만들고, 그 내부에서 또 다른 분파로 나뉘도록 계획했다.
이러한 점조직의 형태 때문에 혁명파 내부에서도 실질적인 혁명파 동지의 숫자를 정확히 알 수 없었다.
결국 결행일에 맞추어 최대한 많은 사람들이 그 모습을 드러낼 때나 혁명파의 정확한 크기를 알 수 있을 터였다.
결행일은 이전과 달리 특별한 행사날이 아니었다.
오히려 경관들과 이빨, 군인들이 경계하지 않을 평범한 날을 노렸다.
점조직인 혁명파들은 조심스럽게 결행일에 대한 날짜를 공유했다.
사르쵸는 중앙 사원을 통해서 이 날짜가 기적적으로 알려지지 않았음을 다인에게 알렸다.
다인이 초조해 하며 말했다.
"어쩌면 첫 번째 시위 때보다 숫자가 적을지도 몰라."
"동지, 걱정마세요. 그때를 후회하고 있던 사람들이 다시 들고 일어날 수 있다는 걸 보여줄 수 있다면, 이번 시위가 실패로 돌아가더라도 다음에 또 누군가 들고 일어날 수 있단 희망을 주는 겁니다. 그것만으로 의미가 있는 거죠."
다인은 동의했다.
결행일 아침.
전과 같은 가두 시위를 목표로 사르쵸가 길 위에 섰다.
사르쵸는 사제복을 입었고 제가 들 수 있는 가장 큰 피켓을 들었다.
[모든 종족은 평등하다.]
평등주의의 기치가 거칠게 적힌 피켓이었다.
이번 시위는 각자가 생각하는 노동자 권리주의, 평등주의를 목표로 했고 이전과 같이 평화로운 가두 행진을 할 생각이었다.
사르쵸는 자신의 사제직을 걸고 사제복을 입었다.
시위대가 배교자가 아니라는 걸 알리기 위해서였다.
중요한 점은 사르쵸 자신 또한 분노하는 자가 평등주의를 위하지 않는다는 직접적인 증거를 아직 찾지 못했다는 것이다.
'우리의 목소리가 너무 작기 때문에 분노하는 자께서 아직 발견하지 못했을 지도 몰라.'
거의 동시에 다인이 자신의 동지들을 데리고 나타났다.
[혁명은 끝나지 않는다.]
[꼬리가 권리인가?]
[통일절의 피를 기억하라.]
각각의 문구가 적힌 피켓과 띠를 두른 사람들이 나타났다.
다인이 말했다.
"당장은 이것 뿐인가?"
"조금 더 기다려봅시다."
그때 눈에 익은 동지 하나가 다인에게 달려왔다.
"다인 동지!"
"무슨 일이야?"
"사람들이 장소를 잘못 알고 이미 광장에 모였습니다."
"뭐? 광장엔 사람이 많을텐데… 우선 이쪽으로 불러."
"그게 아닙니다. 직접 가셔야 됩니다."
재촉하는 말에 다인과 사르쵸는 서로의 눈치를 살피다 빠른 걸음으로 이동했다.
광장에 사람들이 모여 있었다.
통일절 행사에 모였던 사람들만큼이나 많았다.
다인이 의구심으로 말했다.
"뭐야? 무슨 일이지?"
"다인 동지, 정신 차리십쇼. 저 사람들 모두가 동지를 기다리고 있었습니다. 사람이 너무 많아서, 길목에서 모일 수 없었던 겁니다."
다인과 일행이 다가가자, 웅성이던 이들이 다인을 보고 가볍게 환호했다.
다인은 상기된 얼굴로 광장 가운데로 걸어갔다.
모두가 가슴 주머니에 책자 하나를 꽂아두고 있었다.
모두가 혁명파 동지였다.
누군가 중얼거렸다.
"5천명은 넘을 거야."
"5천명? 농담해? 광장의 절반만 채워도 1만이야"
사르쵸가 걱정스럽게 말했다.
"이렇게 많이 모일줄은… 어떻게 합니까, 동지?"
"우선, 좋아. 계획대로 시청 광장으로 이동해야겠어. 우선은 사람들 집중 좀 시키고."
잠시 혼란하던 다인은 눈빛을 다잡았다.
다인은 광장 단상으로 올라가서 외쳤다.
"노동자 동지들! 반갑습니다. 다인이라고 합니다. 공장에서 손을 잃었고, 더이상 받아주는 공장이 없어 내쫓겼습니다. 모두 절 아시진 않겠지만, 꼭 제가 아니더라도 저 같은 친구가 한둘 정도는 있을 겁니다. 그런 점에서, 우린 모두 동지라고 할 수 있을 겁니다."

Sarcho decided to meet up with Dain separately because although it wasn't certain, they suspected that the Fang agents were suspicious of the true nature of the attack on Sarcho. So Sarcho believed it was necessary to act cautiously, and Dain agreed.
They met again in a vagrant village on the outskirts of the city. Groups of wanderers, or vagrants, had been there for a long time, and some even said all species had existed as vagrants since ancient civilizations. Apart from that, vagrants were always seen as outcasts and often suppressed for being perceived as threats. They mainly earned money by selling crafts or fortune-telling, or they were hired for one time physical labor jobs.
Among the buildings carelessly put up with wooden boards, Sarcho said, "Do you live here?"
"Yes."
Dain raised her right hand. "Because my hand is like this, there's no place that accepts me, and I couldn't afford rent."
"I have money for you to find a place in Shubanel."
"That's not why I called you."
Embarrassed, Sarcho fell silent.
Dain invited Sarcho into her shabby abode—it might be too generous to even call it that. Only a thin board separated it from the neighboring house, and there was no distinction between the ceiling and the roof. The soil floor was also wet from the rain of the day before.
"You said you want to help the revolutionaries, right? Properly this time?"
"...Yes."
"Do you have a plan?"
Sarcho replied, "How many revolutionaries are there in the city besides you?"
Dain lightly tapped the table constructed with one leg and nails.
"Be quiet. I can't tell you until I trust you completely."
"...Alright."
Seeing Sarcho's disappointed face, Dain said, "I'll only say the situation isn't good. We're restructuring the revolutionaries' network. Those previously involved are being watched by Fang, so they can't be approached easily. I thought they would participate in the revolution again some day…but most are scared."
"But there are people like you, Dain."
"...Yes."
Sarcho said, "I know some newspaper reporters. They have access to the temple, and a few are close to me."
"They wrote the articles about you, didn't they?"
"The Order occasionally receives revelations from the Angry One. Just as many reporters come and go as there are at the city hall."
"So?"
Sarcho said, "I will tell them to write the truth."
"The truth?"
"That the revolutionaries are not rebels, but just factory workers among us..."
Dain snorted. "Do you think any of those reporters would care about that truth? You think they'd risk their lives for such a cause?"
Sarcho was silent for a moment. "...I can threaten them."
"What?"
"Each newspaper is different, but for morning newspapers, the order goes to the printing house in the early morning. There aren't many people at such printing houses. Replacing one article isn't impossible."
"You think the guards will just let that happen?"
As Sarcho reached into her pocket, Dain tensed up for a moment. What Sarcho pulled out was a crumpled piece of paper. She unfolded it to reveal a map of Shubanel with numbers and what appeared to be a route scribbled by Sarcho.
Then Sarcho said, "The night patrol routes of the guards are fixed and almost always consistent. Not all, but some printing houses are on the outskirts of the city, mostly off the guards' patrol routes. We should be cautious of the Fang agents, but according to our high priest, most of them have left Shubanel because they believe the city to be cleared. I can even go alone."
Dain blankly stared at Sarcho.
"You were really going to do it, weren't you?"
"Yes."
Dain examined the map carefully while listening to Sarcho's plan. It wasn't one backed up by nothing but enthusiasm. The map showed cold, calculated planning. It seemed doable.
Dain then shook her head. "No."
"No?"
"Even if it's successful, we don't know how the public will react. There will be immediate information control."
As Sarsho lowered their head in disappointment, Dain added, "...But, if combined with another plan, it might be useful."
"Another plan?"
"So far, successful revolutions often had the Empire's involvement. The most famous being the Rubeil slave labor camp, which involved outside supporters from the Empire."
Sarcho replied, "...I'd prefer not to rely on them if possible."
"I'll say the same. Relying on external forces undermines the purity of the revolution. The more you lean on external forces, the more people will resist. Then the number of people willing to join the revolution would also decrease… What I'm trying to say is, along with external support, the revolutionaries themselves must also be deeply invested and ready to act at any time."
"You're talking about working on both the inside and outside."
Dain nodded. "Yes. To do so, there must be an environment in which people can rally behind our cause. Simply informing people of the truth isn't enough to move them. People need to be ready to accept that truth."
"You're talking about the network you mentioned earlier."
"Exactly."
"How do we...go about that?"
Dain said, "...That's the problem. We need to persuade each person, and we need to do it without being detected by those who oppose us… We've already failed once, and we might fail again. A second failure might be the end."
"...."
"Do you think you can do it? It will become a thing of the past. You've already taken a bullet from me. I don't think you've fulfilled your responsibility yet…but you don't need to forcefully jump into this. That would rather bother us."
Sarcho looked up. "Dain. A year ago, I never imagined I'd be having this kind of conversation. But now I'm here. I've been wondering what changed me."
"Was it Garil's death that changed you? Sympathy? Or the truth that only you know and others don't?"
"All of it seems right. But there's something that can't be explained by sympathy and truth alone."
"What is it?"
Sarcho made an awkward smile. "I don't really know. But I want to get involved to find out. If you and the revolutionaries agree, that is."
Dain slightly nodded. She understood what Sarcho was saying. Even Dain didn't know why she was doing all of this. This was not going to help her survive, nor was there any guarantee of happiness. It was no different from gamblers casting dice. Sometimes Dain thought this was just a struggle towards self-destruction, no different from suicide, but as Sarcho had said, there was something unexplainable about it.
"Okay, come along, comrade."
While Dain rallied the workers, Sarcho did what they could by strengthening personal relationships with newspaper reporters, and at the same time, drawing out stories about crimes that were continuously overlooked within Shubanel. At first, everyone felt awkward or uneasy discussing it, but once they were full from delicious food and drunk from alcohol in a private setting, they spoke without filter. Through this, Sarcho learned about the criminal acts committed by the nobles and factory owners. Sarcho was able to find out about the close relationship between real estate prices in Shubanel, factory owners, and loan sharks.
A reporter, drunk to the point that their nose was red, said, "I mean, Priest, listen. It's easy to manage the complaints of the workers. First, let's say you listen to some of the workers' demands. Maybe reduce their working hours by an hour. But then, around the same time, nobles who own properties raise the rent. The cost of living becomes tight, so workers borrow money from loan sharks. They can't repay the debt, right?
"So a few workers who are in debt ask for a raise. Then the factory owners argue that they've already given what was asked for, and then the workers plead to increase their working hours. The factory owners get angry, asking why they are now reversing things back to how they were before, and make them work even more than before."
Sarcho said, "Does nobody think that's...a problem?"
The reporter replied, "Those who should know, do know. They ain't called slaves outright, but being a laborer is no different from being a slave. In some respects, it's even worse than being a slave. A slave has a direct relationship with their owner. And the issue could be resolved by simply killing the owner.
"A laborer, on the other hand, is intertwined in the entire societal system, so killing one person won't resolve anything. Think about it, if a laborer kills a factory owner, does the factory disappear? Another factory owner would just purchase it. That's all. Class used to be unstable in the past, but modern class structures are way more solidified. They aren't easily shaken."
Such drinking sessions weren't only beneficial for Sarcho. The next morning, the reporters would wake up with pounding headaches, vaguely recalling the conversations from the previous night. Then they would go in and out of the city hall, enjoy meals offered by the nobles and accept bribes from factory owners, and then they would occasionally remember the things they had said.
Some reporters grew uncomfortable around Sarcho due to the probing questions and avoided Sarcho. However, some genuinely enjoyed Sarcho's drinking sessions. They pondered whether their alcohol-induced confessions were, in fact, their true innermost feelings, or articles they wanted to write but never did.
Meanwhile, Sarcho continued the personal investigations into how the capitalists oppressed the laborers and accumulated their illegal and unethical fortunes. All this information was relayed to Dain, who then used it to rally workers.
With Sarcho's information being based on clear evidence rather than simple rumors, it more than convinced Dain's comrades, but actually made them directly confront their future uncertainties and pains, enlightening them to the fact that the injustices inherent in the societal structure were not due to their personal failures.
Dain's challenge was to somehow calm and hide these rising flames from within. Now, the people had come to understand the injustices, question why they couldn't live happily, recognize that there was no real difference between the Tailless and Full Tailed, and struggle with the unacceptable idea that they suffered because of the defeats their Tailless ancestors faced.
Print shop workers covertly printed pamphlets, newsboys handed out the pamphlets while selling newspapers, carpentry workshops made picket signs, textile mills snuck out extra fabrics, and dye factories smuggled out dyes.
However, Dain was resolute that it wasn't time to move yet. Even though her comrades were eager to, they had to wait for the right moment to create a larger impact. Sarcho also agreed. And there was another issue. Dain believed that it was dangerous for the previous revolutionary faction to gather as a single group, so she planned for individuals to create their own factions, and within those factions, further sub-factions would be formed.
Due to this small organizational group structure, even within the revolutionary group, the exact number of true revolutionaries could not be precisely measured. Ultimately, they would only find out how big they had gotten when as many members as possible showed themselves on the appointed day. They did not pick a special event as before. Instead, they aimed for a typical day when the guards, Fang, and soldiers would be less vigilant.
The revolutionaries in small groups cautiously shared the date of action. Sarcho informed Dain through the central temple that miraculously, the date remained unknown to outsiders.
Dain anxiously said, "Perhaps our numbers will be less than during the first protest."
"Comrade, don't worry. If we can show that those who regretted how things turned out back then can rise again, even if this protest turns into a failure, it provides hope that someone else will rise once more in the future. That alone has meaning."
Dain agreed.
On the morning of the D-day, Sarcho stood in the street aiming for a protest similar to before. Dressed in priestly robes, Sarcho held the largest picket sign possible.
All races are equal.
It was a sign with the banner of equality roughly written on it.
The goal of this protest was to advocate for workers' rights and equality, and just like before, they planned to march peacefully. Sarcho wore priestly attire, staking their status as a priest. This was to convey that the protesters were not apostates.
An important point was that Sarcho themself had not yet found direct evidence to prove that the Angry One did not support equality.
'Perhaps our voices are too small for the Angry One to have noticed.'
Then almost simultaneously, Dain appeared with her comrades.
The revolution is not over.
Is a tail a right?
Remember the blood of unification day.
Each individual emerged with their own slogan written on their pickets and bands around their heads.
Dain said, "Is this all for now?"
"Let's wait a little longer."
At that moment, a familiar face came running to Dain.
"Comrade Dain!"
"What happened?"
"People have mistakenly gathered at the square already."
"What? There will be many people at the square... Call them here first."
"No, you should go there yourself."
Dain and Sarcho exchanged glances and quickly walked over there.
There was a crowd gathered in the square. There were as many people as there had been during the unification day event.
Dain then said with suspicion, "What is this? What's going on?"
"Comrade Dain, get it together. These people were all waiting for you. There were so many of them that they couldn't gather on the streets, so they gathered here."
As Dain and her group approached, the murmuring crowd saw her and lightly cheered. With a flushed face, Dain walked to the center of the square.
Everyone had a booklet tucked into their shirt pockets. They were all members of the revolutionary faction.
Someone mumbled, "There must be over 5,000 people."
"5,000? Are you kidding? Even if only half of this square is filled, that's 10,000!"
Sarcho then said, concerned, "With so many gathered...what should we do, comrade?"
"For now, it's a good thing. We should move to the city hall square as planned, but first, have the people focus."
Dain, who was taken aback for a moment, regained her composure and shouted from the podium, "Fellow workers! Nice to see you. My name is Dain. I lost my hand in a factory accident and was thrown out since no factory would hire me. You may not all know me, but in one way or another, everyone might have a friend or acquaintance who has been through something similar. In that sense, we can all be comrades."
Dain talked of the rights that workers inherently deserved, explained how the entire system was built upon the foundation of the aristocratic distinction between Full Tailed and Tailless, and revealed that the nation's authorities had no intention of fixing such an unjust system.
When Dain spoke, everyone stayed silent, and when she finished, they shouted in agreement.
Dain then talked about the bloody suppression during the previous unification day protest.
"That day, we failed. We lost many comrades, and so did I. This fact was hidden, and the city officials named them traitors, evil ones who clung to the Empire. But we know the truth."
Dain stomped her foot.
"That's right. We know the truth. They were our friends, colleagues, husbands, wives, children, and parents. Yet they returned to us not only as a handful of blood, with their honor shattered. We lived on, keeping the truth suppressed even though we knew it."
Sarcho saw some in the crowd shedding tears, while others glared with clenched fists. Of course, they weren't glaring at Dain. They were glaring at the soldiers who shot the unarmed protestors, or perhaps at their past selves, who had to suffer in silence.
"But no more. We will no longer remain silent. We will reveal this truth to everyone."
As soon as Dain finished her speech, leaflets were distributed. As planned by Sarcho, they were newspapers printed from the printing house. The front page of the newspaper had an article about the unification day protest and its behind-the-scenes story.
There were several guards at a distance, but they didn't dare approach. They hesitated, wondering what to do next.
When Dain suggested moving from the central square to the city hall square, everyone agreed.
Stepping down from the podium, Dain tapped Sarcho on the arm.
"Lead the chant."
"You mean…me?"
"Your voice is loud. Do it."
Sarcho looked hesitant.
"H…how should I say it?"
"You're one of us. Say what needs to be said."
"Oh, okay."
Sarcho nodded, then rolled up their sleeves and walked forward. Although some murmured at the sight of Sarcho in priest's robes, the simple fact that Sarcho stood next to Dain seemed to make them trust Sarcho.
Sarcho shouted aloud, "All people are equal!"
The crowd echoed, "ALL PEOPLE ARE EQUAL!"
For Sarcho, it was an experience like no other. Sarcho wasn't alone in this crowd. It wasn't just Sarcho's voice. It was everyone's.
Sarcho led the crowd and loudly chanted, "Tails are not rights!"
"TAILS ARE NOT RIGHTS!"
From the second and third floors, windows opened, and people looked down at the protesters. Some murmured among themselves, while others gestured for those inside to come and look at the protestors. Some were waving pamphlets, and Sarcho recognized them as the pamphlets of the revolutionary faction. Soon, a few people ran out from their homes.
"Even if we all die!"
"EVEN IF WE ALL DIE!"
Sarcho shouted their throat raw, and tears welled up in Sarcho's eyes, threatening to fall.
"The revolution does not end!"
"THE REVOLUTION!"
The crowd roared back.
"DOES NOT! END!"

던전을 클리어하고 나와 몇 시간, 이신우는 하수도 비밀 시설에서 얻어 나온 서류를 빠짐없이 정독했다.
안티스컬이란 시갈드 장군을 주축으로 하여 황제의 계획을 저지하기 위해 만들어진 집단이며, 동시에 언데드가 되지 않기 위한 연구를 하는 프로젝트의 이름이기도 했다.
"그중 언데드가 되지 않기 위한 연구에 관한 기록이 이곳에 자세하게 나와 있어. 간단히 말하자면 저주가 침입하지 못하는 육체를 만들기 위해 미리 육체를 마법적으로 가공하자는 것이 계획의 핵심이었지."
"그래서? 성공한 거야?"
"아니."
본인도 언데드여서일까, 굉장히 흥미 깊은 목소리로 물어 오는 진에게 이신우는 뚝 끊어지는 단호한 목소리로 대꾸했다.
그렇다. 계획은 다방향으로 진행되었으나 그들 모두가 하나같이 좌절되었다. 실험을 받던 이들이 폭주하는 경우도 적잖았고, 아예 마나를 못 쓰는 몸이 되어 버리는 부작용도 허다했다.
오히려 이곳, 산성독 실험을 한 곳은 그나마 선방한 편이었다. 실험 대상이 죽기는커녕 오히려 강화되었으며, 비록 언데드로 전락하였다고는 하나 기억과 이성 또한 보존할 수 있었으니까.
'지금의 폴들이라면 설혹 인간과 만난다 해도 증오심에 휩쓸리지 않을 수 있겠지.'
모든 언데드는 자신의 의사와 관계없이 인간에 대한 증오를 지닌다. 이것은 언데드의 본능에 새겨진 암시와도 같은 것이었다. 그렇기에 인간이 언데드를 적대하는 것이기도 하다. 비록 이신우는 제국에 도착하는 그 순간부터 언데드였기에 그것에 대해선 잘 몰랐지만!
'과연 시갈드 장군은 지금 어떤 상태일까.'
보고서에 따르면 그는 황제의 계획을 저지하기 위해 여러 방면으로 세력을 모으고 있었으며, 한편으로는 자신이 이끄는 세력을 포함해 자신까지도 안티스컬 실험에 적극적으로 참여하고 있었다고 한다.
그는 과거 결국 황제에 반하여 세력을 일으켰음이 분명한데, 그럼에도 불구하고 저주를 막지 못한 것을 보면 끝내 그 역모는 실패했을 것이다. 그 결과 그가 과연 어떻게 되었을까? 지금까지 언데드의 몸으로라도 살아 있을까? 만약 살아 있다면, 그의 이성은 어떤 상태일까?
거기에 대해선 언젠가 확인할 날이 오리라. 굳이 이신우가 앞장서서 알아내려 할 필요는 없었다. 그보다 앞서가고 있는 선배들이 이미 많이 있으니 말이다.
"다른 용사들은 이 사실을 알고 있는 거야?"
"아마 알고 있지 않을까? 굳이 내가 나서서 확인할 생각은 없지만 아마 그럴 거야."
물론 하수구 던전에서 우연히 알게 된 일이기는 하지만 비밀 시설은 제국 내 곳곳에 감추어져 있었다. 지금 그 대다수가 던전화되었다고 가정한다면, 선배 용사들이 그중 일부나마 찾지 못했을 이유가 없었다. 적어도 이신우는 그렇게 생각했다.
"퀘스트는 깼지?"
"인벤토리랑 채팅 채널까지는 얻어 냈어."
마치 시범이라도 보이듯 가죽 주머니를 인벤토리에 넣었다 빼내어 보이는 진. 이신우는 그것을 보며 고개를 끄덕이곤 그로부터 주머니를 받아 들었다.
그 안에는 그가 말한 대로 최소 2레벨로 시작하는 언데드들의 각 부위 뼈가 꽉꽉 들어차 있었다. 심심치 않게 3레벨 뼈도 보였다.
"사냥은 어땠어?"
"막상 하기 시작하니까 그렇게 힘들진 않았어. 이 몇 시간만으로도 조금쯤은 전투에 익숙해진 기분이야. ……웃어도 돼."
"아니, 원래 그런 거야."
이신우는 뼈의 확인을 마치고는 고개를 들어 진과 마주했다. 푸른 귀화가 이글이글 타오르고 있는 그의 얼굴이 이신우의 코앞까지 다가와 있었다.
"이제 날 동료로 받아 주는 거겠지?"
"물론이지. 하지만 그 전에 확인해 두고 싶은 게 있는데, 네가 이 세상에 떨어지면서 신에게서 받은 능력은 뭐야?"
"으음, 그건…… 하긴 너도 언데드니까 괜찮겠지."
진은 짧게 갈등했으나 이내 이신우의 전신을 훑곤 미미하게 고개를 끄덕이며 재차 입을 열었다. 그 입에서 나온 것은 어느 의미로는 이신우가 예상했던, 하지만 어느 의미로는 전혀 예상하지 못했던 능력이었다.
"사실 나는 죽어도 되살아나는 능력이 있어. 죽음의 축복이라는 능력인데, 저주의 마력을 흡수해 축적한 힘을 축복으로 바꾸어서 내가 죽더라도 부활이 가능하게 해 주는 거야."
"저주의 마력? 아."
"응, 그래서 지금도 마력이 축적되고 있어. 그리 많은 양은 아니지만……."
지금 이 대지에는 언데드화 저주의 마력이 넘쳐 나고 있다. 진은 저주 내성이 없는 대신 스킬 하나로 저주까지 해결한 케이스였던 것이다. 영락없이 그와 같은 '보이지 않는 심장'을 갖고 있을 것이라 생각했던 이신우에게는 상당히 의외였다.
"물론 여태까지 계속 축적한 마력을 다 합쳐도 두 번 부활하는 게 한계지만 말이야."
"네가 계속 달리기만 했던 건 그 스킬의 영향도 있었겠네."
"부끄럽지만…… 그렇지."
이신우는 속이 후련해졌다. 어쩐지 아무리 해골마로의 영락이 슬프다 해도 끊임없이 달리기만 하는 것은 조금 광적이지 않은가 생각했는데, 알고 보니 그의 행동에는 스킬 발동에 필요한 에너지를 비축하겠다는 목적 또한 있었던 모양이었다.
"한 번 죽고 나니까, 다시 죽는 게 너무 무서워져서. 진진에게는 차마 말하지 못했지만 어쨌든 그래. 한심하지?"
"아니, 이해해. 아주 절절히."
이신우가 제국에 떨어지자마자 큰 어려움 없이 적과의 전투를 결심할 수 있었던 것은 99번이나 되는 부활 기회가 있었기 때문이었다. 만약 그도 진과 비슷한 스킬을 지니고 떨어졌더라면 그 비슷한 행동을 했을 것이다.
'그나저나 내 능력과 비교하면 상당히 미묘한데.'
얘기를 듣자 하니 아무래도 진의 능력에는 횟수 제한이 없는 모양이기는 했지만, 아무래도 스킬을 한 번 구사하기까지 모아야 하는 마력의 양이 상당히 많은 모양이었다.
즉 재수가 없으면 부활에 필요한 마력을 미처 다 모으기 전에 허무하게 죽어 버릴 수도 있는 것이다. 그리고 아마도 그것이 그를 더욱 겁쟁이로 만들었겠지. 신은 실로 심술궂은 양반이라고 그는 새삼스레 생각했다.
"저주 내성과 신성 내성은?"
"둘 다 있어. 궁극이야. 아무래도 저주 흡수는 궁극의 내성에서 발전된 형태라나 봐."
"역시."
흡수는 궁극의 내성에서 발전된 형태…… 일단 마음 속 메모장에 적어 두기로 하며 이신우가 고개를 끄덕였다. 진은 부활이라는 말을 듣고도 태연히 고개를 끄덕이는 이신우의 모습에 살짝 안도했다.
"그렇게 말하는 걸 보니 너도 나랑 비슷한 능력을 받았나 보네. 혹시 나만 이런 건가 했어."
"음, 부활의 조건이 조금 다르긴 하지만."
이신우는 보이지 않는 심장에 대해 말해 주었다. 진이 껄끄러워할 수도 있겠지만 자신과 동병상련이라 할 수 있는 그를 속이고 싶지 않았기 때문이었다. 역시나 진은 그를 부러워했다.
"앞으로 97번?! 부럽다……!"
"하지만 그래도 횟수 제한이 있다는 게 성가셔. 그래서 지금 내 목표는 최대한 죽지 않는 거야. 목숨이 하나뿐인 것처럼, 마치 언데드가 아닌 것처럼."
"……그래, 나도 같은 생각이야."
진이 애초에 배우고 싶었던 것 또한 이신우의 그러한 자세였다. 자신과 비슷한 상황에서 절망하지 않고 꿋꿋이 버티는, 오히려 앞으로 나아가는 그 의지!
그러나 이신우는 진의 이글거리는 시선이(사실 귀화는 언제나 이글거리고 있었지만) 부담스러웠는지 슬쩍 고개를 돌리며 말했다.
"그걸로 끝은 아니지? 받은 게 더 있지 않아?"
"아, 음…… 일단 해골마가 되는 과정에서, 정확히는 [다크 본 호스]가 되면서 4레벨이 된 것도 있고. 그리고 [빛의 후예]라는 스킬이 마지막이야."
"그게 뭔데? 빛의 속도로 걷어찰 수 있게 되는 거냐?"
언젠가 꼭 해 보고 싶었던 대사 중 하나를 들먹이는 이신우에게 진은 매정하게도 고개를 젓고는 말했다.
"빛의 축복을 받아서 민첩의 성장 속도가 세 배가 돼."
"……성장 속도라는 부분이 조금 애매한데 구체적으로는?"
그건 빛의 후예가 아니라 샤아의 후예라고 해야 하는 것이 아닐까 생각하면서도 이신우는 보다 자세히 캐물었다. 진은 아무런 망설임 없이 보충 설명을 해 주었다. 그것이 얼마나 대단한 것인지 스스로는 짐작도 하지 못하고서.
"그 어떤 이유로든, 타인이 민첩을 1 얻을 때 나는 3을 얻는 모양이야. 그게 내 업이라나 뭐라나."
"어떤 이유로든……?!"
개사기였다! 어떤 이유로든 세 배라니 업적을 달성해도, 민첩과 연관된 스킬의 레벨을 올려도, 신약을 먹어도 타인의 세 배 효율을 본다는 얘기가 아니겠는가! 과연, 해골에 말이라는 핸디캡까지 짊어진 진이기에 얻을 수 있었을 법한 사기 스킬이었다.
"네가 놀랄 정도면 좋은 능력이긴 한가 봐? 하긴 여태 계속 달리기만 했는데도 스킬 레벨이 오르거나 무슨 빨리 달리기 업적 같은 게 달성되면서 민첩이 쑥쑥 오르긴 했어. 처음에는 500 정도였던 것 같은데 지금은 800 가까이 되네."
"800?!"
민첩만으로 이미 이신우를 뛰어넘은 상태이지 않은가! 과연 그 끔찍한 속도가 납득이 갔다. 진은 레벨 업에 따른 스테이터스 효율 증가를 제외해 놓고 따지면 이미 어지간한 6레벨과도 비벼 볼 수 있을 법한 민첩을 지니고 있었다!
'가만.'
그 시점에서 이신우는 퍼뜩 생각했다. 그렇다면 혹시 자신이 뼈 강화로 진을 강화해 줄 때도 이 능력이 적용되는 것이 아닐까……?
만약 정말 그렇다면 이신우와 진의 궁합은 상상 이상으로 터무니없는 결과를 낳게 될 것이다. 진 본인은 당연히 어마어마한 성과를 이룰 수 있을 테고, 그런 진의 등에 타고 전투를 벌이는 이신우 역시……!
'신은 이걸 예상하지 못했을까?'
범상치 못한 둘의 업이 만나 터무니없는 상승효과를 이룬다. 이 세상의 신인 그녀라면 충분히 이것을 짐작하고도 남았으리라.
그렇다면 신은 그들이 언젠가 함께하게 될 것을 예상했을 수도 있고…… 어쩌면 그렇게 되도록 유도했을 가능성마저 있다. 단순한 심술로 그들을 언데드로 만든 것이 아니라, '평범한 인간들로는 이룰 수 없는' 일을 그들을 통해 이루고 싶었던 것일지도 모르지.
……어쩌면 그냥 아무 생각도 없었을 수도 있지만 말이다.
"너도 다른 능력이 있어?"
"아."
깊은 생각에 빠져 있던 탓에 눈앞에 진이 있다는 사실마저 잊고 있었다. 그는 대답을 기다리는 진을 보곤, 자루에서 2레벨짜리 뼈 하나를 꺼내어 들곤 씩 웃으며(그런 느낌으로) 답했다.
"물론 있어. 애초에 네 능력 얘기를 꺼낸 것도 전부 이것 때문이었고."
"대체 무슨 능력이기에……?"
"그건 지금부터 네 몸에 직접 알려 주지."
"뭣……?!"
"처음엔 조금 머리가 아플 수 있으니까 조심해."
어째선지 진이 경악하며 뒤로 물러서고 있었지만 이신우는 그에 개의치 않고 외쳤다.
"뼈 강화!"

"Did you wait a long time?"
In just 13 hours, Jin had returned with the leather bag Lee Shin Woo had given him completely filled, speaking like a girlfriend who had arrived late to their meeting place. Of course, Lee Shin Woo didn't even have a girlfriend before, so he wasn't bothered at all and spoke.
"It's alright, since I was busy reading this."
"What is it?"
Lee Shin Woo raised and showed the bundle of papers to Jin, who carefully thrust his head forward; the edges of the papers were gradually weathering away and disappearing with every gust of wind. Jin likewise didn't know the Empire's language, but he could read the title of the documents without much difficulty.
"The Anti-Skull... Plan?"
"You wanna read it?"
"Yeah..."
Originally, he didn't really like reading very much, but Jin thought that there was something more to these papers than just a waste of time; yet he couldn't joke like that as Lee Shin Woo's face was much too serious.
Ultimately, he nodded his head, and Lee Shin Woo laid one of the papers on the ground, which best summarized the current state of affairs, so that he could read it easily. Lee Shin Woo then turned his head back to the papers. It was the last page.
"This is... Did the Empire have a force that knew about the impending curse and was preparing for it by any chance!?"
"Ah, so you didn't know."
For a few hours after clearing and leaving the dungeon, Lee Shin Woo thoroughly scrutinized the data he'd acquired from the sewer hidden facilities.
Anti-Skull was lead by General Seagald, and was a group created to prevent the Emperor's plan; at the same time, it was the name of the project that researched ways to prevent them from becoming undead.
"There're detailed records written here about their research into preventing them from becoming undead. In laymen's terms, at the heart of the research was their attempt to magically create a body beforehand which wouldn't be affected by the curse."
"So what happened? Did they succeed?"
"No."
Was it because he was also undead? Jin asked in a deeply interested voice, and Lee Shin Woo replied firmly, cutting him off.
That's right. The plan progressed in multiple ways, but all of them became frustrated. There were several cases where the tested individuals exploded, and it was common that their bodies wouldn't even be able to use mana anymore.
On the contrary, this experiment with Acid Poison wasn't bad. The test subjects didn't die, and actually became stronger; though they degenerated into the undead, they were able to retain their memories and their reason as well.
'Even if they meet humans, the current Pauls shouldn't be driven by their hatred.'
Regardless of their intent, all undead hated humans. It was like a suggestion engraved into their instincts. Because of that, humans also consider undead enemies. Though Lee Shin Woo didn't really know about it since he was an undead as soon as he arrived in the Empire!
'I wonder what state General Seagald is in?'
Based on the reports, General Seagald was gathering forces through various means to prevent the Emperor's plan, while also actively participating in the Anti-Skull's experiments with his subordinates.
In the past, he opposed the Emperor and certainly raised a force, but considering how he couldn't prevent the curse despite that, his rebellion must've failed in the end. What happened to him as a result? Was he still alive, surviving as an undead? If he's still alive, what would be the state of his reasoning?
The day would come where he'd be able to figure this out. Lee Shin Woo didn't really need to take the lead and figure it out himself. Since there were a lot of seniors already ahead of him.
"Do the other heroes know about this?"
"Wouldn't they? I don't really have any plans to check, but they probably do."
Of course, he had coincidentally learned of Anti-Skull in the sewer dungeon, but there were various secret facilities hidden throughout the Empire. If he assumed that the majority of them had become dungeons, a portion of his seniors should've been able to find them already. At least, that's what Lee Shin Woo thought.
"You did some quests, right?"
"I got the inventory and the chatting channel as well."
As if he were demonstrating, Jin put the leather bag in and out of his inventory. Seeing that, Lee Shin Woo nodded his head and took the bag.
There were different bones that filled the bag to the brim, and they were all bones from at least level 2 monsters, just like Lee Shin Woo had instructed. Rarely, he saw some level 3 bones as well.
"How was your hunt?"
"When I actually got started, it wasn't that hard. It felt like I got a bit used to battle in just a few hours. ...Yeah, laugh it up."
"Nah, it's normally like that."
Lee Shin Woo finished inspecting the bones and raised his head, locking gazes with Jin. His face, which blazed with blue goblin fire, came right in front of his own.
"Now you're going to accept me as your colleague, right?"
"Of course. However, there's something I'd like to check before that. What's the ability you got from God as you were dropped onto this world?"
"Mmm, that's... well you're undead too, so I guess it's fine to tell you."
Jin was briefly conflicted, but soon he scanned Lee Shin Woo's body and slightly nodded his head, and opened his mouth for the second time. In a way, Lee Shin Woo had anticipated what he had to say, but at the same time, his expectations were completely off.
"Truthfully, I have an ability that revives me even if I die. It's an ability called the Blessing of Death; the magic of the curse is absorbed, and the accumulated power is changed into a blessing. Even if I die, it makes it possible for me to revive."
"The magic of the curse? Ah."
"Yeah, that's why I'm accumulating magic even now. It's not very much, though..."
The curse's magic, which transformed people into the undead, was overflowing in this world right now. In exchange for Jin having no curse resistance, his skill took care of it. It was a complete surprise to Lee Shin Woo, who thought Jin would definitely have the 'Invisible Heart' like him.
"Though the magic I've accumulated is only enough to revive me twice."
"So the reason you just constantly ran was because of that skill's effect, huh."
"It's embarrassing, but... yeah."
Lee Shin Woo felt refreshed. He had thought that no matter how depressed Jin was from becoming a Skeleton Horse, just constantly running was too much, but after learning about his ability, he realized that Jin had run to stockpile the necessary energy to activate his skill.
"I've already died once, so I've become afraid of dying again. I couldn't tell Jin Jin, but that's how it is. I'm pathetic, right?"
"No, I understand. Very sincerely."
The reason Lee Shin Woo could decide to fight without much difficulty as soon as he was dropped into the Empire was because he could revive 99 times. If he had arrived with the same skill Jin had, he would've done the same as him.
'In any case, when I compare his ability to mine, it's kind of subtle.'
After listening to him, it seemed as though Jin's ability didn't have a limited number of uses, but it also seemed like Jin's ability would require him to gather a tremendous amount of mana to activate the skill.
In other words, he could futilely die before he gathered the required mana if he was unlucky. That probably contributed to him becoming more of a coward. He suddenly thought that God was truly ill-tempered.
"What about curse resistance and holy resistance?"
"I have both of them. They're maxed out. It seems like my curse absorption is the evolved form of maxed out curse resistance."
"As I thought."
His absorption was the evolved form of maxed curse resistance... Lee Shin Woo decided he'd store away that information for now, and nodded his head. Jin felt relieved when he saw Lee Shin Woo unperturbed and nodding his head, even after hearing about his revival ability.
"So you received an ability similar to mine, huh. I wondered whether I was the only one like this."
"Yeah, though my revival conditions are a bit different."
Lee Shin Woo explained the effects of Invisible Heart to him. Jin could've been really uncomfortable hearing it, but he didn't want to lie to someone he sympathized with. As expected, Jin was jealous of him.
"You have 97 more lives!? I'm so jealous...!"
"But the number of lives is annoying. So my goal right now is to die as little as possible. Acting as though I only have one life, and that I'm not undead."
"...Yeah, I agree with you."
From the start, Lee Shin Woo's attitude was something that Jin also wanted to learn. That attitude, where he didn't succumb to despair and endured firmly, despite being in a similar situation, and pressing forward!
However, Lee Shin Woo seemed burdened by Jin's blazing gaze (though in reality, it was always blazing), and slightly turned his head away and spoke.
"That's not all, right? Isn't there more that you got?"
"Ah, yeah... In the process of becoming a Skeleton Horse, or more precisely, a [Dark Bone Horse], I became level 4. And lastly, I got a skill called [Child of Light]."
"What's that? Does it let you kick at the speed of light or something?"
Amongst the several lines he'd always wanted to say, Lee Shin Woo mentioned one of them. Jin then cold-heartedly shook his head and spoke.
"By receiving the Blessing of Light, my agility growth rate increases by three times."
"...Growth rate is kind of vague, so what does it mean in more detail?"
Even as he thought that Jin should be called the Child of Char instead of the Child of Light, he asked for more details. Without hesitating, Jin elaborated. Without even realizing how amazing his own ability was.
"Whenever I gain agility, for whatever the reason, I gain three agility when others gain 1. That's my karma or whatever."
"Whatever the reason...!?"
That's bullshit! Three times the agility no matter what? Increases in agility from karma, skills, and drinking the shop's medicine would be three times that of any other person! Though it was a cheat skill he could gain only after becoming a Skeleton Horse.
"It seems like it's an ability that's so good that it surprises even you. Well, my agility did shoot up as I continually ran, when my skills leveled up, or when I received some karma for running really fast. I feel like my agility was around 500 at the beginning, but right now it's close to 800."
"800!?"
He already surpassed Lee Shin Woo with just his agility! Now he could understand his fearsome growth rate. If he were to exclude the increase in effectiveness of his other stats, he already had agility that rivaled a level 6's!
'Wait a sec.'
At that point, Lee Shin Woo suddenly thought. If that's the case, then would his ability activate when he reinforces his bones, too...?
If that's actually true, then his compatibility with Jin would result in an absurd outcome beyond his imagination. Jin could naturally attain a tremendous result, and Lee Shin Woo fighting in battle from his back...!
'Did God not expect this?'
These two unusual individuals' karma met and would create a ridiculous synergistic effect. If it's her, who was the God of this world, she probably could've predicted this.
If that's the case, then God had predicted that they'd work together at some point... and there's a possibility that she'd guided them such that they would. She didn't just make them undead simply due to her ill nature, but perhaps she wanted them to accomplish the tasks that 'couldn't be accomplished by normal humans'.
...Though she could've just done it on a whim.
"Do you also have a different ability?"
"Yeah."
He was in deep thought, so he forgot that Jin was right in front of him. He saw Jin waiting for his response, and extracted a level 2 bone from the leather bag; he raised it, smiled mischievously (that kind of feeling), and replied.
"Yeah, I do have one. From the start, all of my abilities are because of this skill."
"What kind of ability could it be for it to...?"
"I'll teach you using your own body."
"What...!?"
"Be careful, since your head might hurt in the beginning."
For some reason, Jin was shocked and stepped back, but Lee Shin Woo wasn't concerned by that and yelled.
"Bone Reinforcement!"

"Thats what I thought. Even something like the second moon, which appears to be a product of advanced science, is actually a Miracle achieved by consuming Faith points."

Aldin continued, "But machines are just tools. They're not important."

".....?"

Aldin recognized these machines well. They were computers.

"하지만 그 전에 가장 확실한 곳을 먼저 찾자. 실은 비타스가 이끄는 군단을 처리하는 과정에서 얻은 재밌는 정보가 있거든."
이신우는 하나의 군단을 구성하던 언데드의 모든 기억을 직접적으로든 간접적으로든 받아들이는 과정에서 제국의 12장군 중 하나인 메타펠에 대한 상세한 정보를 얻게 되었다.
지금 이 순간 언데드로 전락한 놈이 어디에 주둔하고 있을지, 그가 이끄는 군단이 어떻게 움직이고 있을지까지도 말이다.
"너 정말 간이 배 밖으로…… 아, 없지."
"지금 착각하고 있는 것 같은데 12장군과 직접 싸우러 갈 정도로 내가 정신이 없는 건 아냐. 그저 군단의 기억을 뒤지던 중 조금 재밌는 걸 알아냈을 뿐이야."
"넌 네가 일반적인 감성의 소유자라고 아직까지도 믿고 있는 건 아니겠지?"
이신우는 여전히 불안한 기색의 진을 보며 피식 웃고는 설명했다.
"원래 비타스가 이끄는 군단은 이것보다 규모가 두 배는 되었어. 그런데 이동하는 중에 병력의 절반을 잃은 거지. 그럼 이놈들이 어째서 죽은 걸까?"
"지나가던 길에서 보물 포식자들이 합창 대회라도 열고 있던 것 아닐까?"
"재밌는 가설이지만 아냐. 그곳에는 그런 것보다 더 무시무시한 놈들이 있는 거야."
이신우는 그렇게 말하며 만족스럽다는 듯 고개를 끄덕이고 있었지만, 그것을 보는 진의 귀화는 불안하게 일렁였다.
"설마 지금부터 그 무시무시한 놈들을 잡으러 가자는 거야?"
"빙고!"
"고마해 이 미친놈아! 군단의 절반이 죽었다고 네 입으로 말했잖아!"
"아냐, 진. 잘 들어 봐."
이신우의 기억 속에서 언데드들은 공통된 괴로움을 겪었는데, 그것은 바로 산성이었다. 마력이 가득 담긴 뼈를 녹이고 그들의 마력을 무력화할 만큼 치명적인 강산! 그레이트 슬라임이나 애시드 구울의 그것보다도 강력한 산성임에 분명했다.
"비타스는 그 상황을 빠져나오기 위해선 큰 희생을 겪어야 함을 직감하고, 군단의 절반을 제물로 바치고 방향을 선회해서 진군하게 됐어. 왜냐면 보통 스켈레톤들은 산성 내성을 지니고 있지는 않으니까 말이야."
"너……."
진은 이신우가 하려는 말을 이미 깨닫고 있었다. 이신우는 진이 그 무슨 말을 하든 물리지 않겠다는 듯 강인한 어조로 말했다.
"하지만 우린 있잖아. 산성 내성이!"
"애시드 구울보다도 강력한 산성이라며!"
"진, 사람은 향상심을 잃어선 안 돼. 우리가 단순 마력이나 물리력이 좀 강해졌다고 해서 항상 해골바가지나 골렘 같은 거랑 싸우고 있으면, 언젠가 타고난 스테이터스만으로는 저항할 수 없는 강력한 속성을 다루는 놈이 나타났을 때 그대로 황천으로 가게 될 거란 말이지."
"지금 황천으로 가게 생겼잖아, 지금!"
"에이, 걱정하지 말라니까 그러네."
안 그래도 요즘 어지간한 상황은 단판으로 정리되다보니, 재생 스킬을 수련할 시간이 너무 없어져서 곤란하다고 여긴 참이었다. 그런데 갑자기 산성을 다루는 몬스터가 떼거리로 서식하는 지역의 정보를 얻어 냈으니 기쁘지 않을 리가 없었다!
"크라티아에게 알려 주지 않은 것도 그럼……?"
"응. 그 녀석은 확실히 강하지만 스킬 수련을 할 때는 별 도움이 안 되니까."
예상했던 대로의 대답이었다. 진은 이신우의 마음이 이렇게 굳어진 이상 자신이 무슨 말을 하든 그의 결심을 되돌릴 수는 없겠다고 확신하며 힘없이 물었다.
"그래서 그 산성 공격을 쓰는 놈들의 정체가 뭔데? 하이퍼 울트라 애시드 구울?"
"아니, 나무."
"나무……."
진이 도저히 알아듣지 못해 고개를 갸웃했으나 이신우라고 더 해 줄 수 있는 말이 있는 것도 아니었다. 실제로 언데드들의 기억 속에서 그들은 숲을 가득 채우고 있는 나무가 뿜어내는 산성독에 당해 쓰러졌으니까!
"어쨌든 놈들은 나무니까 그 자리에서 움직이지도 못하고, 허탕을 칠 확률은 아예 없어. 그래서 확실한 곳을 먼저 가자고 했던 거야."
"으음, 나무인데…… 나무를 쓰러트려서 뭔가 얻을 수는 있을까? 그건 그냥 식물 아냐?"
"너도 이제 이 세상에 제법 적응했잖아? 모든 일은 반드시 업으로 남는다는걸. 걱정 마, 헛수고는 결코 아닐 테니까."
대충이나마 앞으로 향할 곳과 목적에 대해 설명한 후 이신우는 가볍게 지상을 박차 진의 등 위에 올라탔다. 진은 한숨을 쉬면서도 이신우가 바라는 방향으로 몸을 틀었다. 동화 스킬이 있으니 어디로 가자고 굳이 말을 할 것도 없다.
"네 속도면 아마 몇 시간도 안 걸릴 거야."
"후우, 이거 정말 잘하는 짓인 걸까……."
두 해골 용사는 그렇게 모든 정리를 마친 후 드디어 케헤베를 뒤로 했다. 진의 속도가 속도이다 보니 도시의 정경은 빠르게 멀어져 갔고, 이윽고 점으로밖에는 보이지 않게 된 시점에서 이신우는 아쉬움과 후련함이 뒤섞인 한숨을(기분상) 토해 냈다.
도시 정화뿐만 아니라 근처에서 양조장을 발견하거나, 엘프 용사를 만나거나, 12장군 휘하의 직속 부대 하나를 전멸시키는 등 정말 짧은 기간에 여러 일이 있었지만 이신우에게 있어 제일 중요했던 순간은 크라티아와의 교류라고 할 수 있었다.
'녀석 덕분에 마력 기반 능력이 전반적으로 뻥튀기되기도 했고.'
재능이 뛰어난 용사를 확실한 우군으로 만들었다는 점에서도 나쁘지 않았다. 또한 같은 처지의 언데드인 진에게서 얻을 수 있는 정서적인 안정감과는 또 다른 종류의 감정을 그녀와 대화를 나누면서 얻을 수 있었던 것도, 부끄러워서 직접 말하진 못했으나 적잖이 도움이 되었다.
자신의 감정마저 꾸며 내는 조커가 되었지만 그렇다고 감정이 필요 없는 것은 아니다. 오히려 그렇기에 더더욱 감정의 교류가 필요했다. 크라티아는 그 부족분을 채워 준 것이다.
"너 지금 크라티아 생각하지."
그때 묵묵히 내달리던 진이 갑자기 입을 열어 말했다. 동화 스킬을 깊이 구사하고 있던 것도 아니었기에 이신우는 살짝 놀라 대꾸했다.
"자식 겁나 예리한 거 보소……."
"……."
"크라티아 얘길 꺼내는 걸 보니 역시 네 마음에 들었었나 보지? 아, 또 왜. 왜 흔드냐니까."
"그냥 지면이 울퉁불퉁해서 그래."
진은 씨알도 안 먹힐 구라를 치며 이신우를 괴롭혔다. 역시나 진은 크라티아에게 복잡한 감정을 품고 있었던 것일까. 설마 연애 감정은 아닐 것 같았지만 도저히 감이 오질 않았다.
이신우는 그런 복잡한 마음을 품고 채팅 채널에 접속했다. 긴 거리를 이동할 땐 채팅 채널에 접속하는 것이 반쯤 습관처럼 정착한 것이다.
[이신우 님이 입장하셨습니다.]
[로이드 H.K: 오, 걱정했었는데 그래도 무사히 튀었나 보네.]
[이신우: 선배님도 무사하셔서 다행입니다. 에리안 선배님 덕분에 미리 위험을 피할 수 있었습니다.]
아무리 복잡한 심경이라고 해도 채팅 채널에 접속하자마자 능숙하게 거짓말을 하는 데에는 한 치의 망설임도 없었다. 여기서 대놓고 '아뇨 제가 다 잡았는데요' 하고 얘기라도 했다간 사람 여럿 곤란해지는 것이다.
[프린스 알타니아: 나였으면 그 정도는 잡을 수 있었는데.]
[로이드 H.K: 선제 타격으로 큰 피해를 줄 수 있을지는 몰라도 군단을 상대해 승리를 거두는 건 힘들겠지. 아직 7레벨까지는 많이 남았지? 그 전엔 피차 무리하지 말자고.]
[프린스 알타니아: 큭…….]
[야스노리 아키라: 자신의 부족함을 알고 물러서는 데에는 굉장한 용기가 필요하지. 잘했다, 이신우.]
도망을 치지도 않았는데 잘 도망쳤다고 칭찬을 받는 이 상황에서 빨리 탈출하고 싶어진 이신우. 그러나 이제 막 들어와 놓고 관심이 부담스럽다는 이유로 튈 수는 없었다. 언제나처럼 선배들의 동향 확인을 위해서라도 조금은 더 버팅기고 있어야 했다. 그런데.
[시이노 렌두: 하지만 물러서고 싶어도 물러설 수 없는 상황도 있지.]
[로이드 H.K: 시이노?]
[멘테스 오른: ……위험한 상황이냐?]
앗, 여태까지 한 번도 보지 못한 선배가 등장했다! 더구나 느낌상 제법 고참에 속할 것으로 보이는 선배였다! 하지만 지금 반갑다며 인사나 건네고 있을 때는 아닌 듯 보였다. 시이노 렌두의 목소리가 심상치 않았던 것이다.
[프린스 알타니아: 야야, 예진진 죽을 뻔한 지 얼마나 지났다고 그래. 그래도 넌 제법 잘 도망칠 줄 알잖아.]
[시이노 렌두: 네놈의 시답잖은 도발도 지금은 정겹군…… 하지만 이번엔 아무래도 오래 버티지 못할 것 같아. 12장군한테 걸린 것 같거든.]
[로이드 H.K: 뭣, 너…….]
[멘테스 오른: 위험도 3 지역부터는 언데드끼리 통신도 한다는 걸 다들 알고 있을 텐데. 12장군이 마침 그 근처에 있었다면 걸릴 수도 있는 거다. 그리고 우리는 이미 그 사실을 너희에게 다 한 번씩은 말해 줬어.]
[시이노 렌두: 선배 탓을 하고 싶은 건 아니야. 실은 그 누구의 탓도 하고 싶지 않아.]
[야스노리 아키라: 근육돼지, 네놈…….]
항상 쌀쌀맞은 말을 하는 야스노리 아키라마저 침잠한 목소리를 냈다. 로이드에 이르러선 목소리가 갈라지는 것이 느껴질 정도. 언젠가 예진진이 구조 요청을 했을 때와 비슷한 분위기가 형성되고 있었다.
이신우는 채팅 채널에 들어오는 타이밍이 잘못되어도 단단히 잘못되었다는 생각에 씁, 입맛을 다셨다. 게다가 12장군이라니, 채팅 채널의 누가 가도 도와줄 수 없는 수준이 아니겠는가.
[시이노 렌두: 신입…… 아니지, 이신우.]
[이신우: 네, 선배님.]
[시이노 렌두: 넌 이렇게 죽지 마라. 빨리 성장하고 싶다고 해서 너무 무리하지 마. 이곳에서 우리의 편이 되어 주는 건 시간뿐이니까…….]
[이신우: ……명심하겠습니다.]
[시이노 렌두: 세이라는 지금 없나……. 누군가 세이라에게, 내가 항상 당신을 그리워했노라고 전해 줬으면 해. 그녀의 마음이 얼어붙어 다른 누구를 받아들일 수 없는 것을 알고 있지만, 그럼에도 나는 끝내 그녀를…….]
[프린스 알타니아: 끝까지 어이가 없는 놈이군. 그런 게 제일 민폐란 말이다, 이 바보 놈아.]
[멘테스 오른: 아니, 다 털어 내고 가라. 더 하고 싶은 얘기는?]
[시이노 렌두: 그리고…… 그걸로 됐어. 어차피 보너스로 얻은 인생이었다. 잘…… 아주 잘 즐기고 간다.]
그 말을 마지막으로 시이노 렌두는 채팅 채널에서 나가 버렸다. 그리고 아무도 말이 없다가, 가장 먼저 프린스가 아무 말 없이 채널에서 퇴장했다. 이어서 아키라가, 그리고 로이드가. 이신우도 채널을 나가려 했으나 그 전에 마지막까지 남아 있던 선배가 그를 붙잡았다.
[멘테스 오른: 이신우라고 했지? 6레벨이 되거든 내게 개인 채팅을 걸어라. ……위험도 3 지역 중, 비교적 안전하게 드나들 수 있는 곳을 몇 군데인가 짚어 줄 테니까.]
[이신우: 고맙습니다, 선배님.]
[멘테스 오른: 오랜만에 들어왔는데 기분만 더러워졌어……. 난 상점에 새로 들어왔다는 술이나 먹으러 갈란다. 젠장.]
그것을 마지막으로 그 선배도 퇴장했다. 이신우는 처음으로 감정이 과잉되지도 않고 수상한 꿍꿍이속도 없는, 담백하면서도 후배에게 필요한 최소한의 도움을 주는 선배와 만났다는 생각이 들었다.
그런 사람이 질려서 채널에 들어오지 않게 될 만큼, 이 제국에서는 무수한 용사가 죽어 나갔다는 얘기가 되겠지. 그때.
'아, 근처에 추가됐다.'

Contrary to magic, which could be fully controlled by humans, spirits possessed a power that was erratic and atypical, which couldn't be trusted. So, not only were contractors oppressed and killed, but the Magic Empire also attempted to drive out the spirits from this world.]
He felt like he'd heard something really important at an unexpected moment. Moreover, something she said bothered him: that the Empire was trying to drive out the spirits.
"They attempted to drive them out... With the others?"
[Yeah, probably.]
"So, the Underground Empire wasn't formed by a gathering of eccentric individuals, but by those who were driven out of the Magic Empire."
They were driven out because of the spirits? No, that probably wasn't the only reason. Perhaps those ostracized by the Empire were gathered up all at once and were banished underground, like gathering a bunch of criminals and putting them in prison.
"The spirits must've not liked the underground very much then?"
[It probably wasn't a very conducive environment for them, regardless of the presence of death energy. Though it's a livable place for us Dryads due to your help, Paul Zero.]

The Underground Empire was built by those who had been driven from the surface. If that's the case, then why were they stuck underground... or turning it around, why couldn't they 'return to the surface'?
'And if I'm right, then it's because...'

[Don't look at me like that. It's embarrassing.]
"Hey."

'I think I can fully transform into a human now. Not just the outside, but even the internal organs; a proper human... Ha, like this?'
Why had been so conservative with the Invisible Heart, gathered so much Perium, and attempted to study said Perium... Lee Shin Woo felt skeptical. Indeed, things didn't always go as Lee Shin Woo wanted.
Lee Shin Woo had finally become able to transform into a human.

Baek Saheon opened his eyes.
Or rather, it would be more accurate to say that he hadn't slept a wink.
'Fucking hell.'
Ever since entering 'Horizon Mountain Lodge', his nerves had been on edge, searching for a way to leave this place alive and intact.
Half of his efforts were spent trying to stay on Kim Soleum's good side, carefully walking on eggshells to gauge the guy's mood.
'Son of a bitch.'
He felt no shame about it—it was necessary for survival.
…Even now, as he debated whether to visit Kim Soleum's room, it was for the same reason.
'I need information, anything I can use.'
That lunatic definitely knew something. Baek Saheon was convinced he needed to extract that knowledge to secure a trump card for his survival.
But…
"……"
Was Kim Soleum really a lunatic?
More specifically, why had he… saved him?
Baek Saheon already knew the truth. There had been multiple opportunities at the exhibition for Kim Soleum to kill him or use him as a scapegoat, but he hadn't.
Sure, he had been messed with a few times, but in the end…
'No!'
He probably did it for fun. It's only because keeping me alive would make things more unpredictable and entertaining for that bastard!
Baek Saheon jumped to that conclusion. He'd never encountered such a madman in his life before.
'…Even so, I doubt he'd lie about something important.'
With a strange sort of faith, he opened his door—
Something stood in front of it.
"……!!"
The now-darkened lodge was steeped in shadows, making it difficult to recognize the figure immediately.
A man of similar height to himself.
…It was Kim Soleum.
'Shit!'
Startled, but strangely relieved.
Better him than a stranger. At least Kim Soleum wouldn't try to kill him.
"Hey…"
But as Baek Saheon's eyes adjusted to the dim light, he noticed something in Kim Soleum's hand.
An axe.
"……"
'What?'
An axe?
He almost rubbed his one remaining eye in disbelief before a plausible explanation struck him.
"That's… for self-defense against the killer, right…?"
But then, another thought entered Baek Saheon's mind.
The texts Kim Soleum had been sending.
[watch out for serial killers]
What if those texts weren't warnings…
…But a prediction of the future?
"Bye bye."
The axe came down on his head.
The next morning.
A couple leaving their room heard a melody faintly blending with the heavy rain.
Hmm, hmm-hmm, hmmmm, hmm-hmm-hmm.
A hum.
"Isn't that the song that played when our car's GPS broke?"
"Omo, it does sound like it… Is this some local radio station?"
Breathing in the damp, eerie morning air, they held their cassette tape tightly like a treasure as they passed through the hallway to the kitchen.
And then—
"GAAAHHHHH!!"
They saw something stuffed into the kitchen hearth.
It looked like someone had detonated fireworks and toys inside, charring the area completely black.
The burnt remains.
Among the dark-red ashes, two stick-like objects jutted out, bent at odd angles.
And at the end of those sticks…
Shoes.
The sneakers were partially burned, still clinging to what used to be a person's feet.
"Aaaaaack!!"
"Oh my God! Is that… a person?!"
"Aigoo, aigoo, what is this— what's happening— aigoo!!"
The couple's screams of horror echoed through the lodge, quickly drawing the others downstairs.
One by one, the others joined the chaos, their faces pale.
"What's going— AAAAHHH!!"
"Gaaaasp…!"
The students, the middle-aged driver—no one was immune to the panic.
One person, claiming earlier to have a sore throat and only communicating via notes, collapsed to the ground, his face drained of color.
But… weren't there two people who said they were office workers?
'No way…!'
The couple pointed at the burned feet sticking out of the hearth.
"The young man who came with you… is it him? The one with the eye patch?"
The remaining office worker stared at the scorched sneakers, covering his mouth, and gave a small nod.
"AGH!!"
Someone had died.
A person they had talked to just yesterday.
As the realization set in, cries and screams filled the room again.
"Call 119 right now!"
"What the hell is this?! Fuuuuck!!"
"I told you these old kitchens were dangerous! One small fire and look what happens!"
But in their hearts, a small voice whispered doubts.
'Was it really an accident?'
Could a fire burn only a person, leaving everything else untouched… and in such a horrific state?
'Could it be…'
Still in a state of panic, the group scrambled for their phones.
And moments later—
A collective chill ran down their spines.
"T-The phone isn't working. There's no dial tone!"
"Where's the caretaker? Someone just died here!"
But the caretaker, who had promised to take good care of them, was nowhere to be found, as if he'd vanished into thin air.
The dark, rain-soaked mountain surrounding the lodge.
Inside the lodge, only the group and the humming remained…
"……"
"……"
Hmm, hmm-hmm, hmmmm, hmm-hmm-hmm.
Outside, an unrelenting downpour lashed the area, and there were signs that a landslide had occurred overnight, burying the bus stop in debris.
"The road… it's completely buried."
"My car!!"
That's when the group began to realize.
Hmm, hmm-hmm, hmmmm, hmm-hmm-hmm.
Something was seriously wrong.
"I-I swear, that thing… it was moving earlier."
"……"
Near the hearth where the charred remains lay, a small, old analog cassette player emitted the humming sound.
Hmm, hmm-hmm, hmmmm, hmm …
Click.
One of the students switched off the cassette player and pulled something from inside it.
A worn ivory-colored tape.
"……!"
The pale-faced office worker shakily pulled out his notebook, his trembling hands scribbling quickly.
[This looks like the cassette Baek Saheon had…]
"O-Oh my God."
And that's when the nightmare truly began.
Lunchtime.
The lodge's caretaker had apparently prepared a neat meal of soup and rice in advance, but nobody dared to touch it, as if by mutual agreement.
Instead, they nibbled on energy bars and snacks they'd brought themselves, wandering around the lodge in a futile search for a signal to make their phones work.
Unsurprisingly, there was no success.
In the oppressive rain, the isolated mountain lodge felt suffocating and ominous, severed from any external connection.
'This is driving me crazy!'
One of the university students, frustrated by his unresponsive social media apps, angrily tapped at his phone screen before switching it off in irritation.
"Fuck!"
"Dude, you're such a fucking scaredy-cat."
One friend teased, laughing nervously as they pushed each other closer to the legs sticking out of the hearth.
They even took a few photos of the scene, treating it like a twisted joke, though they didn't seem to have much appetite as they left their calorie bars and chocolates untouched.
Despite their mockery, they weren't as calm as they appeared.
They relied on their numbers to feel secure.
'There's three of us, after all.'
Even if someone tried to kill them, they reasoned, no one would target a large group first.
'They'll go for someone alone, or the stragglers.'
That thought seemed to put them somewhat at ease.
"Hey…"
One student turned to chat with his friend, but a peanut-filled chocolate bar was suddenly extended in front of him.
When he looked up, he saw the pale-faced office worker holding out his notebook.
[Would you like some? I don't think I can eat it…]
"Uh, no thanks."
The student replied curtly, and his friend beside him snickered.
"Dude, he can't eat peanuts."
[Ah… I apologize.]
The office worker apologized silently, retreating to the sofa with a dejected air.
Wasn't he the one who'd been introduced as a supervisor?
At first, he'd seemed quite intimidating, but after witnessing his colleague's death, he looked utterly deflated.
'Scared stiff, huh.'
He now gave off the impression of someone who would crumble under even the sliiiightest pressure.
"Hey, wanna bet?"
"Sure, but man, this is too much."
Meanwhile, the other two students went outside for a smoke.
The office worker, still fiddling with his unresponsive phone, cast a dark glance at the hearth before heading upstairs.
And just like that, the room grew silent.
"……"
One student was left alone, uneasily shifting in his seat.
'In the movies, this is the part where someone gets attacked.'
He tapped his foot anxiously, glancing around the room with a wary expression. The presence of a jackknife in his pocket gave him some reassurance, but not for long.
'Shit, why'd they go off on their own?'
Unable to bear it any longer, he decided to go looking for his friends in the backyard.
Gripping the jackknife tightly, he quickened his pace, unnerved by the sensation of something prickling at his back.
He pushed open the back door to the kitchen, which led to the yard.
Click.
A damp, musty smell hit him immediately.
'They're probably under the roof somewhere.'
Surely they wouldn't stand in the rain to smoke, right?
With that thought, he headed toward a storage shed connected by a covered walkway.
But as he walked, a peculiar smell caught his attention.
Something metallic and sharp.
'Iron?'
It smelled like rust, perhaps from the rain leaking into old tools in the shed.
That was his assumption, at least, as he rounded the corner.
"Hey, Park Kyungsoo…"
And then, an overwhelming metallic stench hit, enough to numb the nose.
"H-Huuuh…?"
Inside the backyard shed was an old construction-grade grinding machine.
It seemed like the machine had been used not for wood, but for something else entirely.
Cruuunch.
What should have been sawdust spewing from the discharge chute was instead shredded flesh.
Fragments of torn clothes, blood-soaked meat, and crushed bone were scattered messily across the floor.
"……"
What is this?
What… the hell is this?
For a moment, his brain refused to process the scene, rejecting the horrifying reality. Then, a beat later, the truth hit him like a tidal wave.
He had found his friends.
Turned into minced meat.
"Uuuughk…!!"
As panic overtook him, vomiting and screams erupted from his mouth.
And then, another sound joined in.
From an old audio device came a familiar tune.
Hmm, hmm-hmm, hmmmm, hmm-hmm-hmm.
The sound from the cassette tape.
"Hiiieek!"
The student spun around and bolted, running madly back into the lodge.
Fear and cold terror chased him down to the tips of his hair.
"Hey, why are you running arou—"
"Aaaargh!!"
The student flailed wildly, slapping away the hand that had grabbed his shoulder.
"Don't touch me, you bastard!"
"Whoa, whoa, what the hell?!"
He looked up.
The bewildered faces of the other lodge residents stared back at him.
And there was one thing they all had in common.
The tapes.
That's it!
If the psycho responsible for this was targeting the tapes, and that's what caused all of this—
The student frantically rummaged through his pocket and pulled out his tape.
"Here, look at this! Look!"
His eyes were bloodshot, and spit flew as he shouted.
"I'm throwing this away! Take it! I don't want it, okay?! I've given it up, damn it! I've given it up!"
Thud!
He flung the tape onto the ground, then bolted upstairs to his room, slamming the door behind him.
Only when he locked the door did he finally catch his breath.
"Hah… hah…"
Anxiety darted his eyes around the room.
His mind was plagued by the sight of shredded flesh and broken bones, pounding in his skull like a drumbeat.
Thud.
Thud.
Should he build a barricade with furniture in front of the door?
Thud.
No, that would block his escape route.
Thud.
He glanced at an old lacquered wardrobe in the room, hesitating before pressing himself against the wall beside it, gripping his jackknife tightly.
He stared intently at the door.
Thud…
As his back rested against the wall, his breathing began to settle.
'J-Just try it. Force your way in, I dare you…!'
If someone tried, he'd fucking scream bloody murder while swinging his knife. People would come rushing in, and surely he'd be saved!
He just had to stay alert.
"No way, no way…"
He muttered to himself like a madman, his voice trembling—
Click.
Softly, the wardrobe door creaked open.
The next morning, the student was found in his room, the door wide open to welcome others.
His body was grotesquely swollen, like an overstuffed sausage, bloated from an allergic reaction.
The hiking club had been wiped out entirely.
"Aaaaaahhh!"
In just one day, an office worker and three students had become corpses, plunging the remaining people into total terror.
"It's the inheritance! Someone's killing people to take more of the inheritance, yeah?! I'm sure of it! They're trying to silence us all so they can keep the tapes without any trouble!"
"That guy, the caretaker! That fucker was sketchy as hell! He looked like a psycho!"
"It's a ghost! We're all haunted! Ha ha ha!"
A middle-aged man shouted like a madman, then pushed past the others and ran outside.
"Argh!"
Ruuuumble.
Thunder resounded at just the right moment.
No, it wasn't just thunder. There was another sound mixed in.
BOOOM!
"……!"
"W-What was that?!"
Startled by the deafening noise, everyone turned toward the window.
The civil servant murmured grimly.
"…A landslide."
The landslide had conveniently struck again.
Swept away by the rushing debris, the deranged middle-aged man disappeared down the mountain slope.
AAAAHHHHH…!
His screams faded as he was buried in the muddy earth below.
Rumble… BOOM!
Thunder replaced the humming as it roared outside the lodge, lightning flickering across the stormy sky.
"……"
"……"
A suffocating silence hung over the frozen group of survivors.
Four people remained.
Night two.
The couple, who had spent the day scouring the lodge for a way to contact the outside world, returned to their room, panting.
They'd found no means of escape, but they had discovered something else.
"Hah, hah…"
"Fuck— Shut the hell up and breathe quietly, you moron!"
"Aaack!"
The husband, introduced earlier as the wife's partner, shoved her head roughly before darting out of the living room and up the stairs to the second-floor hallway.
As he ascended, someone cautiously exiting their room happened to meet his bloodshot gaze, startled.
"Hey, you!!"
He was calling out to the office worker who had been communicating through written notes because of his sore throat.
Startled, he quickly fumbled for his notebook to write something, but the man standing before him was faster, shaking something in his hand.
"This, this gold frame…!"
It was the ornate golden picture frame that had been hanging in the living room.
Eyes wild, the man jabbed a finger at the text inscribed inside the frame.
Joyful Mealtime
The rabbit bakes in the kitchen
The deer is caught in the backyard
The pigeon is fattened in the bedroom
The lamb is sliced in the living room

"……!"

A person roasted in the kitchen, ground in the backyard, and bloated in the room.
"The lodge caretaker or whoever is messing with us! This could all be staged—maybe we're being broadcast somewhere! Or maybe… no, they're toying with us, that's for sure!"
The employee widened his eyes, startled by the revelation. Seeing his reaction, the man grew even more convinced and raised his voice further.
"The next one is the living room! Someone's going to get sliced up in the living room! I'm sure of it! We need to find a way out before it's too—"
"Oh."
……
Huh?
That was a response.
"Surprisingly observant. Braun."
"Braun?"
That was the last word the man ever said.
"Awake?"
A throbbing headache greeted him as he regained consciousness.
"Mmph! Mmmmph!"
His voice was muffled—he realized there was a gag in his mouth.
He screamed as loud as he could.
"MMMMMMPH!!"
But the reason for his terror wasn't just the damp, moldy smell of the basement he found himself in or the pitch-black darkness that made it impossible to see more than a few inches ahead.
It was the severed head lying right next to his.
Yes, just a head.
"Mmmph! Mmmmmmph!"
The pale, lifeless face rested on a silver tray mere inches from his nose.
He felt his sanity slipping.
Tears, snot, and cold sweat poured down his face as he desperately screamed for help, though the gag swallowed every sound.
"Hrrrnnph, s-sppph, mmmph!"
"Scared? Try to bear with it—I'm holding back too."
A calm, composed voice responded from somewhere nearby.
The man rolled his eyes frantically, trying to distance himself from the head as he looked up.
And he saw him.
'The office worker…!'
Dressed in black sweats, the younger man frowned as he gazed down at him.
Then, as if in disdain, he looked at the bloodied work gloves in his hand before letting out a sigh and slipping them back on.
Next, he picked up an axe.
"MMMMMPH!!!"
"Why is it that people always scream first, even when they already know what's going to happen? It just tires everyone involved."
"Mmph!! Mmmph!!"
"Let's not waste our energy unnecessarily."
He's insane.
This man—no, this monster—was the killer…!!
The captive wanted desperately to negotiate, plead, fight back, do anything to survive, but his bound body and gagged mouth gave him no options.
Tears streamed uncontrollably down his face.
"Hm, I think I've heard that physical and emotional pain can be alleviated a bit by screaming…? Or, well, something like that."
The office worker's voice was dry, his tone almost clinical as he inspected the blade of the axe.
The edge gleamed as it caught the dim light.
"Reasonable enough, I suppose. Still, I don't find it particularly satisfying."
He adjusted his grip.
The axe swung.
A gleaming arc in the air.
Thud.
Clang…
"……"
"……"
Silence enveloped the basement.
Kim Soleum lowered the axe and, with a slightly brighter tone, remarked,

등 뒤에서 느껴지던 인기척이 멈춰 서자, 마도영 또한 걸음을 멈추고는 뒤를 바라봤다.

"It seems like the problem is that you're just too outstanding, Young Master."
Seo Jae-pil's words, delivered with what looked like an amused laugh, made my face scrunch up involuntarily.
"What the hell is that supposed to mean?"
"Well, everyone's looking for you regardless of age or gender, so it doesn't really make sense to be suspicious of anyone who shows interest in you."
There was one particularly grating word that drilled into my ears.
"What kind of stories have you been hearing that make you say 'regardless of age or gender'?"
"Haha. I heard it from the instructors. Not just the instructors either. Apparently, all the disciples, male and female alike, are quite interested in you, Young Master."
The part about female disciples being interested in me didn't bother me at all. It was the bit about male disciples being interested that got under my skin.
"...Don't even mention such horrifying things."
The mere mention of it conjured images of those certain crazy bastards in my head.
My mind was instantly filled with the revolting sight of those muscleheads from the Bodybuilding Club, flexing and grunting as they discussed me.
Shudder.
I felt like I was about to throw up, so I quickly shook my head to banish those horrifying thoughts.
When I finally regained my calm, I saw Seo Jae-pil watching me have my little breakdown with what looked like fascination.
"Whew. Anyway, the conclusion is that there's no particularly suspicious instructor. Pretty disappointing, all things considered."
I didn't like the way he was looking at me like some kind of test subject, so I tried to jab him a bit, but it had no effect.
"Hahaha. The study of the human psyche is not something that yields results overnight, Young Master."
Looking at this perpetually cheerful bastard, a thought occurred to me.
'Even if I started cursing him out right here, this crazy fuck would probably just get more excited, saying his research subject was having a meltdown.'
I could already picture him gleefully jotting down notes about finding a new research topic.
'Let's just ignore this nutjob for now. How can I catch someone's tail?'
I was mulling it over by myself, but somehow it didn't feel like I was actually alone in my thoughts.
And it wasn't because of Seo Jae-pil grinning away in front of me.
—Hehe. If you're going to act as bait anyway, why not be a little more proactive about it?
It was because my other self, the one obsessed with perfectionism, kept coming up with useful suggestions.
How should I put it?
Rather than thinking alone, it felt more like I was having a discussion with another version of myself.
And thanks to that damn side effect, I was able to organize my thoughts quickly.
"How about this instead? Let's shake them up."
"What kind of approach do you have in mind?"
"Didn't you say it yourself, Physician Seo? That all the instructors are interested in me. So, let's throw out some bait. Me as the bait."
"????"
Seeing Seo Jae-pil's still-confused expression, I elaborated.
"I'm thinking of stirring up some other clubs. I'll give off the impression that I want to switch."
Finally understanding my intent, Seo Jae-pil spoke with a surprised expression.
"That's an excellent idea, Young Master! There's a high chance that Instructor Ma Do-young will also change his behavior, and other instructors will be forced to make some kind of move too."
I nodded at his words.
"And as you continue your counseling sessions, conversations about my movements will naturally come up. It will be easier to spot anyone whose words don't match their actions, or whose behavior seems contradictory."
"As expected of you, Young Master. I think I'm starting to understand why people of all ages and genders end up admiring you. Haha."
"......."
It was clearly a compliment, but it felt like I was being mocked for some reason.
Since I'd decided to shake myself up as bait anyway, I figured I might as well be blatant about it.
"…You want to try out the Theater Club?"
Repeating what I'd just said, Instructor Eun Ryeo was looking at me with a deeply suspicious expression.
The other instructors in the vicinity also turned their gazes toward us.
"Disciple Il-mok. Haven't you already joined the Meditation Club? You even went as far as to establish it yourself."
I answered with a straight face at Instructor Eun Ryeo's point. Acting like I couldn't even feel the gazes of the instructors watching us from around.
"I think I was a bit hasty in creating a club without properly looking into the existing ones first, Instructor."
"So now you want to experience other clubs?"
"That's right, Instructor."
My clean, simple answer somehow made Instructor Eun Ryeo's face crumple up.
It was quite the sight.
This person, who always maintained a poker face, was now sighing heavily.
'Something about this feels similar to that day when Chu Il-hwan attacked me.'
Come to think of it, I'd completely forgotten about it because of Chu Il-hwan's subsequent attack.
She'd suddenly shown up and given me a strange lecture before leaving. Now, with that same look of pity, she sighed and spoke.
"Really, you don't have even a speck of responsibility, do you?"
I felt like I'd heard something similar back then too, but now wasn't the time to explain that.
I had bait to shake.
"Even if I were to transfer out of the Meditation Club, there would still be three people left, so it wouldn't be a big problem, would it?"
"Are you seriously saying that right now..."
Instructor Eun Ryeo, who seemed about to argue further, soon let out another big sigh before returning to her usual cold mask.
"Fine. Since you were at the main headquarters when the club system was first introduced, you wouldn't have had a proper chance to look into the other clubs. Since Disciple Il-mok's case is special, I'll let it slide this time."
After receiving her permission, I turned to leave the teachers' building.
I could feel the gazes of several of them following my back.
That afternoon, Il-mok headed to that familiar clearing for the first time in a while.
The place that once only Il-mok and Jeong Hyeon used to visit, and which had now become something like a clubroom for the Theater Club.
Baek Cheon, who had basically become the owner of the place, welcomed Il-mok with a very bright face.
"Haha! I believed in you, Young Master Il-mok!"
"What are you talking about?"
For some reason, this time it was Bang Mi-hwa who stepped forward, letting out a laugh.
"How mischievous of you to ask that, hohoho. I also believed that you would naturally return to the Theater Club, Young Master."
"Hahahaha! A man as outstanding as Young Master Il-mok deserves to be in the spotlight with me, Baek Cheon!"
"Others may not be worthy, but you're certainly qualified to be my 'partner' in acting, Young Master. Ohohoho."
Watching this pair of crazy actors laugh their heads off, Il-mok already felt dizzy.
'Damn it. I haven't even been here for a minute.'
Ma Do-yeong's constant nagging had made the Meditation Club uncomfortable, but being here now made the Meditation Club seem like a paradise.
Just as Il-mok was considering escape, a savior appeared in the unlikely form of Instructor Eun Ryeo.
"Alright. Stop chattering and start practicing. This is club time, not playtime."
Eun Ryeo got dizzy every time she came here too.
"Also, disciples are equals among themselves, so address him as Disciple Il-mok. How many times do I have to point this out?"
When Eun Ryeo sorted out the situation, the expressions of Baek Cheon and Bang Mi-hwa, who had been chatting with Il-mok, completely changed.
They might be crazy about everything else, but they were surprisingly serious when it came to acting.
"Then, as always, we will begin with vocalization practice, Instructor."
Since Baek Cheon and Bang Mi-hwa were the ones leading the club time anyway, Eun Ryeo just nodded and stepped back.
Immersed in their practice—or rather, immersed in the image of themselves practicing—Baek Cheon and Bang Mi-hwa began to lead the other students.
And Eun Ryeo watched the scene while sneaking glances at Il-mok.
'He definitely has impure motives, but there's nothing I can do about it.'
In her mind, Il-mok was already branded as a playboy.
The reason Eun Ryeo bothered to accept such an Il-mok was simple.
Instructor Eun Ryeo's gaze had left Il-mok and turned toward Jeong Hyeon.
'How did she end up liking such a playboy? Tsk.'
It was a click of the tongue not of disdain, but of pity.
Perhaps because this was the first time in a while, Jeong Hyeon kept stealing glances at Il-mok.
Sensing Jeong Hyeon's gaze, Il-mok, who had been half-heartedly doing voice exercises, casually approached her.
Of course, Il-mok stopped at exactly ten feet away as always.
When Il-mok approached, Jeong Hyeon startled and stuttered.
"It's, it's been a while, Young Master."
"Don't we see each other every day in class?"
"I-in the clearing, I-I mean… It's been a while… right?"
"I suppose so. Haha. Have you been enjoying the club?"
He wanted to ask if she was having fun with Baek Cheon, but since Baek Cheon was right there, he phrased it more diplomatically.
Of course, Jeong Hyeon wanted to say no. But…
'Everyone's watching, how can I say I don't like it…'
Her inherent shyness had her glancing around nervously, and in the end, she couldn't help but lie. "I-it's been fun."
Seeing Jeong Hyeon glance toward Baek Cheon as she answered, Il-mok nodded, thinking 'as expected.'
'Her feelings for Baek Cheon haven't changed, I see.'
She was really going down a tough path.
"Hang in there, Disciple Jeong Hyeon."
"Th-thank you."
When Jeong Hyeon blushed at Il-mok's encouragement, Instructor Eun Ryeo, who was watching, let out a big sigh.
That sigh seemed to be a cue for Bang Mi-hwa to Il-mok.
Deep in her acting, she had only just noticed Il-mok chatting with Jeong Hyeon.
"Disciple Il-mok! You need to focus on practice."
Saying this, Bang Mi-hwa pulled Il-mok over along with Ha Young and Ju Seo-yeon.
Il-mok was surrounded by three women while Jeong Hyeon watched the four while being ten feet away.
Watching this pitiful scene, Eun Ryeo sighed once again.
Day by day, managing her expressions was becoming more difficult.
But soon Eun Ryeo returned to her characteristic cold expression.
She could sense someone approaching.
"What brings you here, Instructor Ma Do-young?"
It was because Ma Do-young, the instructor in charge of the meditation club, had suddenly come to the clearing.
"Excuse me, Head Instructor. If it's alright, may I have a word with Disciple Il-mok?"
Eun Ryeo, who found the sight of Il-mok laughing while surrounded by women quite distasteful, readily agreed.
"Disciple Il-mok!"
Hearing her call, Il-mok, who had escaped from among the women, soon spotted Ma Do-young.
"What brings you here, Instructor?"
Ma Do-young's forehead veins bulged at the seemingly innocent face, but he maintained his smile as he spoke.
"Let's move somewhere else to talk first."
Saying this, Ma Do-young turned and left the clearing with a swift motion, and Il-mok followed.
But Il-mok stopped after a few steps. He judged it dangerous to go to some secluded place where there were no people. There was a pretty high chance this guy was a rat.
Sensing that the presence behind him had stopped, Ma Do-yeong also stopped and turned around.
"Disciple Il-mok. What exactly are you trying to do?"
"What do you mean?"
"Huuu. I went so far as to accept the position of Meditation Club advisor at your request, and now you want to switch to another club. Do you really think this makes any sense?"
At Ma Do-young's question, Il-mok answered with a confused expression.
"I thought you would want me to, Instructor, so I decided to switch clubs."
"...What kind of twisted logic is that, saying I would want it?"
"During class, during club activities… You seemed uncomfortable around me, didn't you? Since I couldn't dare ask you to change your assignment, I, a mere student, decided to be the one to transfer."
"......."
Ma Do-young was momentarily speechless.
Not because Il-mok's words were logical.
'That's just because you're lazy as hell!!!'
Blood rushed to his head, making it difficult to even speak. And on top of that…
'Dammit!! If I try to force him to stay, I risk raising suspicion, just like the Vice Hall Master said. But if I let him go, he'll end up transferring to another club.'
If that happened, all his plans to monitor Il-mok closely and look for opportunities would fall apart.
That meant his chance to achieve merit would also disappear.
He couldn't stop him, but he couldn't just let him go either.
'Should I just kill him? Should I just kill him now? If I kill him, wouldn't that still count as achieving something?'
With all other paths blocked, the final option kept popping into Ma Do-yeong's head.
Meanwhile, back in the Meditation Club's room.
With Il-mok, the one who had dragged them into the club, and Ma Do-yeong, the instructor in charge, both absent…
"Sigh."
"Why the hell are we..."
The sighs of the trio, filled with complex emotions, echoed one after another.

While Snowhite Rabbit was swinging her whip while Viscountess Great Prawn Pearl was burning down a village. The world split into a hundred pieces. From every crack, screams leaked out.
Amethyst's world was a kaleidoscope.
